title: Parables of Lostness
shortSummary: Luke 15 presents three powerful parables told by Jesus that reveal God's heart for the lost and the joy in heaven over one sinner who repents. These stories emphasize God's grace, mercy, and the call to repentance, illustrating the value of every individual to God. The chapter also contrasts the responses of the lost and the self-righteous, encouraging believers to embrace forgiveness and restoration.
timeline: c. AD 27-30 - Jesus' public ministry in Galilee

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God and teacher who tells the parables to reveal God's love and mercy toward sinners.

keyCharacters.name: The Younger Son
keyCharacters.description: A son who demands his inheritance, wastes it in sinful living, and returns repentant to his father, illustrating repentance and restoration.

keyCharacters.name: The Father
keyCharacters.description: Represents God’s forgiving and compassionate nature, welcoming back the repentant sinner with open arms.

keyCharacters.name: The Elder Son
keyCharacters.description: The older brother who resents the father's grace toward the younger son, symbolizing self-righteousness and lack of compassion.

keyCharacters.name: Pharisees and Scribes
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who criticize Jesus for associating with sinners, prompting the teaching of these parables.

definitions.definition: Tax collectors who were often despised by Jewish society for collaborating with Roman authorities and were considered sinners.
To feel sincere remorse for one's sins and turn away from them toward God.
A well-fed calf reserved for special celebrations, symbolizing joy and restoration.
Servants who worked for wages and did not share in the family inheritance, representing a lower status.
Religious scholars and teachers of the Law in Jewish society, often involved in interpreting Scripture.

outline.heading: Jesus Welcomed by Sinners and Criticized by Pharisees
outline.description: Jesus attracts tax collectors and sinners eager to hear Him, while the Pharisees and scribes murmur against Him for associating with such people, setting the stage for His teaching on God's mercy.

outline.heading: Parable of the Lost Sheep
outline.description: Jesus tells of a shepherd who leaves ninety-nine sheep to find one lost sheep, illustrating God's relentless pursuit of sinners and the joy in heaven when one repents.

outline.heading: Parable of the Lost Coin
outline.description: A woman diligently searches for one lost coin among ten, symbolizing God's diligent care for each lost sinner and the rejoicing of angels over repentance.

outline.heading: Parable of the Prodigal Son
outline.description: The story of a younger son who squanders his inheritance but returns repentant and is warmly received by his father, demonstrating God's forgiveness and restoration for repentant sinners.

outline.heading: The Elder Son’s Resentment
outline.description: The elder son’s anger at his father’s grace toward the prodigal highlights the danger of self-righteousness and the call to rejoice in the salvation of others.

application: Recognize and rejoice in God's relentless love and pursuit of sinners, encouraging prayer for those who are lost.
Embrace repentance personally, knowing that God eagerly welcomes and restores those who turn back to Him.
Avoid self-righteous attitudes by celebrating the forgiveness and salvation extended to others.
Practice forgiveness and compassion in relationships, reflecting the father’s heart in the parable of the prodigal son.

keyVerses.text: I say unto you, that likewise joy shall be in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, more than over ninety and nine just persons, which need no repentance.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the immense value God places on the repentance of even one sinner, emphasizing heavenly joy over restored sinners.

keyVerses.text: And he arose, and came to his father. But when he was yet a great way off, his father saw him, and had compassion, and ran, and fell on his neck, and kissed him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse powerfully illustrates God's compassion and eagerness to forgive and restore repentant sinners.

keyVerses.text: For this my son was dead, and is alive again; he was lost, and is found. And they began to be merry.
keyVerses.significance: It summarizes the central message of restoration and celebration when a sinner returns to God.

keyVerses.text: It was meet that we should make merry, and be glad: for this thy brother was dead, and is alive again; and was lost, and is found.
keyVerses.significance: This verse calls believers to rejoice in the salvation of others, countering attitudes of resentment or judgment.
